articles.author: Elizabeth Palermo, LiveScience
articles.summary:
A lot of the fear surrounding spiders is based on myths, not facts, according
to the experts who study these eight-legged creatures.
articles.title: 5 Spooky Spider Myths Busted (Discovery)

articles.author: Dan Dake
articles.summary:
Bioethics (Vol. 28, No. 8, October 2014) is now available online by
subscription only. Articles include: "A framework to link international
clinical research to the promotion of justice in global health" by Bridget
Pratt and Bebe Loff " Stigmatization and denormalization … Read More
articles.title: A New Edition of Bioethics is Available (bioethicscom)

articles.summary:
(_JS Communications_) Today the leading journal PLOS ONE published research
that provides underlying scientific support for a fundamentally new type of
natural alternative to the use of antibiotics in livestock feeds for growth
promotion and disease prevention. This research comes at a time when
stakeholders across the globe, including national health regulators, are
looking to avoid usage of antibiotics in livestock due to concerns they pose
threats to public health.
articles.title: Avivagen publishes evidence for natural alternative to antibiotic use in livestock (Eurekalert)

articles.author: By JOE DRAPE
articles.summary:
Win, place and show selections for Friday’s Breeders’ Cup races at Santa Anita
Park.
articles.title: Breeders’ Cup Picks: Day 1 (New York Times)

articles.author: Daily Mail: None Given
articles.summary:
Daily Mail: A scientist who helped to discover the Ebola virus says he is
concerned the disease could spread to China given the large numbers of Chinese
workers traveling to and from Africa. Peter Piot, director of the London
School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said on Thursday the scenario of the
deadly virus reaching China was 'not rocket science.' 'The concern I have is
that I don't think you can really stop people from traveling. These patients
will show up in any country in the world, but China...
articles.title: China is at serious risk from #Ebola outbreak, says Peter Piot (climateark)

articles.author: Bob King
articles.summary:
Looks like we dodged a bullet. A bullet-shaped asteroid that is. The 70-meter
Goldstone radar dish, part of NASA's Deep Space Network, grabbed a collage of
photos of Earth-approaching asteroid 2014 SC324 during its close flyby last
Friday October 24. These are the first-ever photos of the space rock which was
discovered September 30 this year by […]
articles.title: Earth Dodges a Bullet — New Radar Images of Asteroid 2014 SC324 (Universe Today)

articles.summary:
Japanese climbing ferns are able to engineer the sex of nearby ferns to ensure
equal numbers of male and female plants.
articles.title: Ferns can change their neighbour’s sex (Science Alert)

articles.author: Bioethics Pundit
articles.summary:
(New York Times) - Some people exposed to the Ebola virus quickly sicken and
die. Others become gravely ill but recover, while still others only react
mildly or are thought to be resistant to the virus. Now researchers working
with … Read More
articles.title: Genes Influence How Mice React to Ebola, Study Says in ‘Significant Advance’ (bioethicscom)

articles.summary:
A population of endangered giant tortoises, which once dwindled to just over a
dozen, has recovered on the Galapagos island of Española, a finding described
as "a true story of success and hope in conservation" by the lead author of a
study published today (Oct. 28).
articles.title: Giant tortoises gain a foothold on a Galapagos Island (Biologynews)

articles.author: Ishraq Al Tal
articles.summary:
The UAE Telecommunications Regulatory Authority (TRA) delegation representing
the Arab League at the ITU Plenipotentiary Conference 2014, held in Busan,
Korea for the past three weeks, announced that the ITU has approved a work
paper submitted by the Arab League. The paper was based on a UAE suggestion to
support youth innovations in ICT. In […]
articles.title: ITU approves Arab League work paper submitted by UAE on supporting Youth Innovations in ICT (AME )

articles.summary:
ProKure V is a powerful disinfectant recommended by the CDC, to use on viruses
such as common cold and flu, and even EV-D68 and Ebola.
articles.title: Killing The Deadly Enterovirus On Surfaces: ProKure Safely Kills Dangerous Pathogens in Seconds (24-7 Pressrelease)

articles.summary:
Researchers using a combination of different imaging techniques have found
structural abnormalities in the brains of people with chronic fatigue
syndrome, according to a new study. The results suggest a potential role for
imaging in diagnosing and treating the condition.
articles.title: MRI identifies brain abnormalities in chronic fatigue syndrome patients (Eurekalert)

articles.summary:
CAPE CANAVERAL Fla (Reuters) - Heeding a lesson from history, designers of a
new generation of U.S. rockets will include escape systems to give crew
members a fighting chance of surviving launch accidents such as the one that
felled an unmanned Orbital Sciences Antares rocket on Tuesday.
articles.title: New U.S. rockets include crew launch-escape systems (reuters)

articles.summary:
Commercial and recreational fishers from the Hauraki Gulf have joined
conservationists in a landmark effort to save a threatened species of
seabird.Representatives from the fishing industry, government, environmental
groups and...
articles.title: Pledge signed to protect threatened NZ bird (APN)

articles.author: By CORAL DAVENPORT
articles.summary:
The refrain is a stopgap between two politically untenable positions: the
denial of climate change and the embrace of policies to address it.
articles.title: Political Memo: Why Republicans Keep Telling Everyone They’re Not Scientists (NY Times)

taking off on a test flight in Southern California's Mojave Desert, a witness
